learning_outcomes.description: State and accurately explain the underlying drivers, macro forces and key concepts that you appreciate enable safe technology innovation.
Explain the different legal approaches that underpin legal regulation of new technology.
Evaluate the effectiveness of different legal approaches to the regulation of the Internet and AI.
Apply relevant Australian and international laws to contemporary problems involving the Internet and AI.
Reflect on your own understandings of how technology, such as AI and the Internet, impact society and business, particularly businesses operating internationally.
Have sufficient practical skills to provide advice to potential clients with Internet and AI issues.
Have knowledge and skills to help you predict how AI will impact the future practice of law and legal businesses.

assessments.task_description:
There will be 7 mini quizzes. Each quiz will be online, and will be multiple choice, true/false and the like.

For Quiz 1 to 6 will be 5 questions. For Quiz 7, there will be 10 questions.

In total, there will be 40 questions. Each question is of equal weight.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Instructions will be provided in class. You will need a computer connected to the Internet in class to do the assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The assessment will be released on 8 March 2026.

You will examine the application of Internet law in relation to a current issue. You will have a choice of topics. Further details will be provided on Blackboard. The word limit will be 2,200 words. The word limit should be detailed on the first page of the assessment. Footnotes are not included in the word limit and a bibliography is not required. Any words over the word limit will not be marked.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct .

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You will be using Cadmus to complete this assessment. Cadmus is an online environment for written assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Group presentation 30% (10 minutes plus approximately 5 minutes Q&A)

In Seminar Weekend One, you will form a small group (3-5 students). You may choose your own members. 

Your final assessment task will be a group presentation.

Topic choice

Your group will choose a topic from a list of provided topics relating to AI legal issues. During the semester we will discuss AI legal issues, but also note areas where the law is inadequate, or is failing to address potential AI harms. We will also discuss current and emerging areas of law reform and litigation. This task gives you the opportunity to choose an area of law, conduct research, and present your ideas as to how the law could achieve better outcomes.

You are encouraged to discuss your proposed topic with the Course Coordinator.

Due date

In class, you will be shown how to book a session for your group presentation. Session times will be released for week 13 (29 and 30 May). There may also be some times released for the first week of exam block if required (exact date and time TBC, depending on student enrollment numbers).

Format

Each oral presentation session will be approximately 3 hours, to allow up to 10 to 12 groups to present in that time period. All group members must be present for the session. Your group will be presenting to the course coordinator and a small group of fellow students. The presentation will be recorded.

Material that may be used to support your oral presentation (e.g. handout) will be specified in the assessment topic document that will be provided to you in the seminars.

Group input

All group members must contribute to selecting, developing, researching, and presenting the topic. The oral component of the presentation may be given by a single group member or some/all of the members. However, all group members must be prepared to answer questions during the Q&A component. Every group member will receive the same mark, unless a case is made otherwise. Two assessors will review the presentation (in-person or a recording) to provide moderation of grades.

Resources to support your group work will be provided on the course BlackBoard and discussed in class.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
After your group presentation, you will submit an INDIVIDUAL reflection on your experiences during this task. This will include reflection on your topic choice, your contribution to the work, and the group work process. Further guidance will be provided in class.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Why is the Internet different?

Introduction

  • Doing Business Online and Doing Business Internationally
  • Why is the Internet Different?
  • Can the law keep up?
  • Does business drive the law or does the law drive business?



Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Why is the Internet different? Introduction Doing Business Online and Doing Business Internationally Why is the Internet Different? Can the law keep up? Does business drive the law or does the law drive business?

learning_activities.topic:
Internet Jurisdiction

  • What is jurisdiction and why is it important?
  • What laws apply to doing business online and where can you sue or be sued?



Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Internet Jurisdiction What is jurisdiction and why is it important? What laws apply to doing business online and where can you sue or be sued?

learning_activities.topic:
Customer Acquistion

  • Online branding
  • Online advertising (including Google and Facebook Ads)
  • Domain names and domain name disputes
  • Affiliate programs
learning_activities.topic_description: Customer Acquistion Online branding Online advertising (including Google and Facebook Ads) Domain names and domain name disputes Affiliate programs

learning_activities.topic:
Converting Users to Customers

Converting Customers: Contract formation issues, with a focus on electronic contracting

Unfair contracts

Generally, key legal issues and business risks when doing business internationally, from a business perspective


Learning outcomes: L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Converting Users to Customers Converting Customers: Contract formation issues, with a focus on electronic contracting Unfair contracts Generally, key legal issues and business risks when doing business internationally, from a business perspective

learning_activities.topic:
Social Media

Social Media - The Power of the Platforms

  • Social media revenue models
  • Historic social media cases
  • Liability of Platforms
  • Liability of business owners using social media
  • Recent social media legal issues
  • Online safety



Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Social Media Social Media - The Power of the Platforms Social media revenue models Historic social media cases Liability of Platforms Liability of business owners using social media Recent social media legal issues Online safety

learning_activities.topic:
AI Legal Issues - What is AI and what legal issues arise because of AI?

Introduction to key concepts in respect of AI, including generative AI. We will explore how AI works from a technical viewpoint, so that students will be better able to understand legal issues that may result. We will then introduce, at a high level, legal and ethical issues that may arise because of the use of AI technology in business and society. 

We will consider responsibility - who should be legally responsible in relation to the development and use of AI technologies?

If time permits, we will review laws relating to data (relevant to data used to train AI).


Learning outcomes: L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: AI Legal Issues - What is AI and what legal issues arise because of AI?
learning_activities.topic_description: AI Legal Issues - What is AI and what legal issues arise because of AI? Introduction to key concepts in respect of AI, including generative AI. We will explore how AI works from a technical viewpoint, so that students will be better able to understand legal issues that may result. We will then introduce, at a high level, legal and ethical issues that may arise because of the use of AI technology in business and society. We will consider responsibility - who should be legally responsible in relation to the development and use of AI technologies? If time permits, we will review laws relating to data (relevant to data used to train AI).

learning_activities.topic:
New AI Laws and New Laws Needed Because of AI

We will consider whether new laws are needed to regulate AI, and if so, what those laws should be. Do current laws adequately regulate AI, and if not, is regulation needed? Additionally, we will consider whether there are specific areas or industries where new laws may be needed due to AI. Laws regulating AI in other jurisdictions (such as Europe) and for specific uses of AI (such as medical uses and use of deepfakes in advertising) will be considered.


Learning outcomes: L03
learning_activities.topic_title: New AI Laws and New Laws Needed Because of AI
learning_activities.topic_description: New AI Laws and New Laws Needed Because of AI We will consider whether new laws are needed to regulate AI, and if so, what those laws should be. Do current laws adequately regulate AI, and if not, is regulation needed? Additionally, we will consider whether there are specific areas or industries where new laws may be needed due to AI. Laws regulating AI in other jurisdictions (such as Europe) and for specific uses of AI (such as medical uses and use of deepfakes in advertising) will be considered.

learning_activities.topic:
AI’s impact on the practice of law, ethics and society in general

We will consider how AI may impact the practice of law. This will be a broad inquiry, including the impact of AI on law firm business models, how AI will impact work in law firms and corporate legal departments, the training of lawyers, and the work done by lawyers. We will also examine how AI may impact legal process, such as dispute resolution, contract negotiation and M&A transactions. We will consider the ethical issues raised the uses of AI in the legal profession. Broadly, we will consider the impact of AI on society, business, employment and democracy. We may also consider how AI may impact the justice system, fraud detection, policing (e.g. predictive policing), and sentencing.

Learning outcomes: L05, L07
learning_activities.topic_title: AI’s impact on the practice of law, ethics and society in general
learning_activities.topic_description: AI’s impact on the practice of law, ethics and society in general We will consider how AI may impact the practice of law. This will be a broad inquiry, including the impact of AI on law firm business models, how AI will impact work in law firms and corporate legal departments, the training of lawyers, and the work done by lawyers. We will also examine how AI may impact legal process, such as dispute resolution, contract negotiation and M&A transactions. We will consider the ethical issues raised the uses of AI in the legal profession. Broadly, we will consider the impact of AI on society, business, employment and democracy. We may also consider how AI may impact the justice system, fraud detection, policing (e.g. predictive policing), and sentencing.

learning_activities.topic:
Wrap Up - Can the law keep up?

We will synthesis the key themes of the course across Internet and AI law, drawing together an overarching "legal theory" where possible.

We will also discuss current trends and unsolved legal questions.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_title: Wrap Up - Can the law keep up?
learning_activities.topic_description: Wrap Up - Can the law keep up? We will synthesis the key themes of the course across Internet and AI law, drawing together an overarching "legal theory" where possible. We will also discuss current trends and unsolved legal questions.
